oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Misses Black School in southwest corner of Pulteney Park; Bank Alley
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Misses Black School in southwest corner of Pulteney Park; Bank Alley. It was in operation from 1873-1880. It appears to have been operated by the Misses Sarah and Julia Black, and according to the Geneva newspaper was closed because of the prevalence of diptheria at that time. Sarah died in 1899; Julia lived until at least after 1910.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Presbyterian Church in Pulteney Park off of South Main Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: First Presbyterian Church in Pulteney Park off of South Main Street. Church in which Elizabeth Blackwell "received in 1849 the first degree of M.D. ever conferred upon a woman." Chapel on site of schoolhouse (1796 - 1822) in which both Jedediah Chapman and Davenport Phelps preached. To the left is the "Water Cure" (since 1914, the Pulteney Apartments). Three stories at the northeast corner of the 52 square foot building, built at Williamson's Geneva Hotel in 1796. The church's bell, still in use in the 1850's, welcomed Lafayette to the reception in this "Public Square" on June 8, 1825.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Vail, James G.
